Key Arguments: The bill could lead to a single 'truth' being promoted, suppressing alternative narratives.
There is a concern that the bill could reinforce groupthink and be manipulated by those with bad intentions.
The bill is seen as a tool for censorship and control of truth by the government.
The current media and political landscape already suffer from bias and propaganda.
The bill could be used to target minor political parties and independents, suppressing alternative economic policies.
The bill contradicts international human rights agreements on freedom of opinion and expression.
Notable Quotes: This bill can easily encourage and reinforce group think, the rationale being ‘it must be truth if enough people believe it.’
The internet has often proved to be the only source of truth for increasing numbers of the population who have lost all faith in both major political parties and the tame mainstream media.
The current Communications amendment bill is just an example of Labor’s version of how to control 'truth.'

Australia is signatory to the United Nations’ Universal Declaration of Human Rights of 1948 which says that, ‘Everyone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers.’
